name: 1,3-di-p-tolyl-2-thiourea
Reason: 1,3-di-p-tolyl-2-thiourea has a melting point that is influenced by several structural components. The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings and a methoxy group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. The methoxy group can also contribute to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +20°C.
